{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = White Day |type = |image = White Day 001.jpg |imagesize = |caption = White Day cake |nickname = |observedby = [[Japan]], [[South Korea]], [[Malaysia]], [[Taiwan]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Macau]], [[Vietnam]] and [[mainland China]] |litcolor = White |longtype = |significance = |begins = |date = March 14 |duration = 1 day |frequency = Annual |scheduling = Same day each year |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = [[Valentine's Day]] }} {{Infobox Chinese |s=白色情人节 |t=白色情人節 |p=Báisè qíngrén jié |katakana =ホワイトデー |hangul=화이트데이 |vie = Valentine Trắng |malay = Hari Putih }} '''White Day''' is a day that is marked in [[Japan]], [[South Korea]], [[Vietnam]],<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/02/14/travel/valentines-day-south-korea/ | title=In South Korea, Valentine's Day is all about the men | first=Frances | last=Cha | work=[[CNN]] | date=14 February 2013 | accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> [[Taiwan]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://taiwantoday.tw/ct.asp?xItem=215132&ctNode=435 |title=untitled Taiwan Today |website=taiwantoday.tw |publisher=[[Government Information Office]] | accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> [[Hong Kong]], [[Malaysia]] and [[China]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.china.org.cn/archive/2007-03/13/content_1202804.htm | title=White Day Triggers Consumption Enthusiasm | work=china.org.cn | publisher=China Internet Information Center | accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> on March 14, one month after [[Valentine's Day]].
== Observation == [[Valentine's Day#Japan|Valentine's Day]] in countries which observe White Day is typically observed by girls and women presenting chocolate gifts (either store-bought or handmade), usually to boys or men, as an expression of love, courtesy, or social obligation.
On White Day, the reverse happens: men who received a {{nihongo3 |'chocolate of love'|本命チョコ|[[Honmei choco|honmei-choco]]}} or {{nihongo3 |'courtesy chocolate'|義理チョコ|[[Giri choco|giri-choco]]}}<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.japantravelinfo.com/blog/valentines-day-white-day-in-japan/ | title=Valentine’s Day & White Day in Japan | publisher=[[Japan National Tourism Organization]] | accessdate=13 March 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504234139/http://www.japantravelinfo.com/blog/valentines-day-white-day-in-japan/ | archive-date=2014-05-04 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> on Valentine's Day are expected to return the favor by giving gifts.<ref name="uh">{{cite web | url=http://www.crosscurrents.hawaii.edu/content.aspx?lang=eng&site=japan&theme=cal&subtheme=CULTURHOL&unit=JCAL018 | title=White Day (March 14) | work=Cross Currents | publisher=[[University of Hawaii]] | accessdate=13 March 2013}}</ref> Traditionally, popular White Day gifts are [[cookies]], [[jewelry]], [[white chocolate]], white [[lingerie]], and [[marshmallows]].<ref>{{Citation | title = Culture | publisher = Japan 101 | url = http://www.japan-101.com/culture/valentines_day.htm | contribution = Valentine’s day}}.</ref> Sometimes the term {{nihongo3 |'triple the return'|三倍返し|sanbai gaeshi}} is used to describe the generally recited rule for men that the return gift should be two to three times the worth of the Valentine's gift.<ref name = "Iroha">{{Citation | script-title=ja:ホワイトデー | url = http://iroha-japan.net/iroha/A01_event/06_wd.html |trans-title=White Day | publisher = Japanese Culture Iroha Dictionary | language = Japanese}}.</ref>
== Origin == White Day was first celebrated in 1978 in Japan.<ref name = "Iroha" /> It was started by the National Confectionery Industry Association as an "answer day" to Valentine's Day on the grounds that men should pay back the women who gave them chocolate and other gifts on Valentine's Day. In 1977, a [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka|Fukuoka]]-based confectionery company, Ishimuramanseido, marketed [[marshmallow]]s to men on March 14, calling it {{nihongo |Marshmallow Day|マシュマロデー|Mashumaro Dē}}.<ref name="Iroha" />
Soon thereafter, confectionery companies began marketing [[white chocolate]]. Now, men give both white and [[dark chocolate]], as well as other edible and non-edible gifts, such as [[jewelry]] or objects of sentimental value, or white clothing like [[lingerie]], to women from whom they received chocolate on Valentine's Day one month earlier.<ref name="uh"/> Flowers and other gifts are also given on this day. Eventually, this practice spread to the neighboring East Asian countries of South Korea, China, Taiwan and Vietnam. In those cultures, White Day is for the most part observed in a similar manner.
As a note in Japan, if chocolate given to a man a month prior was ''giri choco'', the man may not be expressing actual romantic interest, but rather a [[Giri (Japanese)|social obligation]].
== See also == * [[Giri (Japanese)]] * [[Hallmark holiday]] * [[International marriage (Japan)#History|International Marriage Day]], the coincident day when international marriages were first legalised in Japan * [[Black Day (South Korea)]]

[[File:Cecilia Beaux, Rev. Dr. William Henry Furness, 1886.jpg|thumb|250px|''Reverend Doctor William Henry Furness'' (1886) by [[Cecilia Beaux]].]] '''William Henry Furness''' (April 20, 1802 – January 30, 1896) was an American clergyman, theologian, abolitionist and reformer.
==Biography== Furness was born in Boston, where he developed a lifelong friendship with schoolmate [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]]. He graduated from the [[Harvard Divinity School]] in 1823. At the age of 22 he became the minister of the [[First Unitarian Church of Philadelphia]], which had operated without a minister for 29 years. He served there from 1825 until his retirement in 1875. The congregation grew substantially during his ministry, moving to a larger building in 1828. It moved to a still larger building in 1886, which was designed by his son Frank.<ref name=harvard_square /><ref name= philly-history />
Furness was an ardent [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]] whose attacks on the [[Fugitive Slave Act of 1850|Fugitive Slave Act]] led to a discussion at a cabinet meeting of President [[James Buchanan]] about the possibility of indicting him for treason.<ref name=civilwarphilly>{{cite web |url=http://www.civilwarphilly.net/johnbrown/tourstops.pdf|title=John Brown's Philadelphia|author=V. Chapman-Smith|publisher=Civil War History Consortium|accessdate=August 4, 2016 }}</ref> He was a prominent speaker at the Martyr Day vigil in Philadelphia in 1859, which marked the execution of [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]], who had attempted to spark a slave uprising in the South.<ref name=civilwarphilly/> After abolitionist Senator [[Charles Sumner]] was severely beaten on the floor of the Senate by Congressman [[Preston Brooks]] of South Carolina, he stayed at the Furness home during part of his convalescence.<ref name=philly-history/>
Furness was a student of the life of [[Jesus]], about whom he published several books. He asserted that the miracles attributed to Jesus in the Christian Bible were natural events with rational explanations.<ref name=harvard_square/> He rejected traditional beliefs about Jesus' miraculous birth, saying, "these stories may have been pure fictions ... [or] they were exaggerations of certain simple and very natural incidents, magnified by wonder."<ref>Furness, William Henry (1853), ''A History of Jesus'', Boston: Crosby, Nichols and Company, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZukS02TIVAwC&pg=PA19 p. 19]</ref>
Furness promoted outreach to the Jewish community in Philadelphia. His son Frank was the architect for the new building for [[Congregation Rodeph Shalom (Philadelphia)|Congregation Rodeph Shalom]].<ref name=philly-history/>
He married Annis P. Jenks of Salem, Massachusetts in 1825. They had four children: [[William Henry Furness, Jr.]], a portrait painter; [[Horace Howard Furness]], a Shakespeare scholar; [[Frank Furness]], one of Philadelphia's most prominent architects; and [[Annis Lee Wister|Annis Lee Furness Wister]], an author and translator.<ref name=harvard_square>{{cite web|url=http://www.harvardsquarelibrary.org/biographies/william-henry-furness|title=William Henry Furness|date=September 29, 2012|publisher=Harvard Square Library|accessdate=August 4, 2016}}</ref><ref name=philly-history>{{cite web |url= http://www.phillyhistory.org/blog/index.php/2012/04/reverend-william-henry-furness-a-philadelphia-unitarian/|title=Reverend William Henry Furness: A Philadelphia Unitarian|author=Steven Ujifusa|date=April 19, 2012|publisher=City of Philadelphia|accessdate=August 4, 2016 }}</ref>
==Selected works== * ''Notes on the Four Gospels'' (1836) * ''Jesus and His Biographers'' (1838) * ''[https://archive.org/details/historyofjesu00furn The History of Jesus]'' (1853) * ''Thoughts on the Life and Character of Jesus of Nazareth'' (1859) * ''The Blessings of Abolition'' (1860) * ''The Veil Partly Lifted'' (1864) * ''[https://archive.org/details/jesusheartofchri00furn Jesus, the Heart of Christianity] (1882) * ''[https://archive.org/details/storyofresurrect00furn The Story of the Resurrection of Christ Told Once More] (1885) <gallery> File:Views in Philadelphia and its vicinity - engraved from original drawings (1827) (14765859372).jpg|2nd building: First Unitarian Church of Philadelphia File:Undergroundrailr00lcstil 0712 Furness.jpg|Rev. William H. Furness, from [[William Still]], ''The Underground Railroad'' (1872). File:First Unitarian Church in 1886.jpg|3rd building: First Unitarian Church of Philadelphia (1885–86). </gallery>

{{Infobox philosopher | name = Étienne Klein | image = Salon du livre de Paris 2011 - Etienne Klein - 005.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|4|1|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Paris]], France | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[20th-century philosophy|20th-]]/[[21st-century philosophy]] | alma_mater = [[École Centrale Paris]] | school_tradition = | notable_ideas = | influences = | influenced = }} '''Étienne Klein''' ({{IPA-fr|klɛ̃|lang}}; born 1958) is a French [[physicist]] and [[philosopher of science]], born in 1958. A graduate of [[École Centrale Paris]], he holds a DEA ([[Master of Advanced Studies]]) in [[theoretical physics]], as well as a [[Ph.D.]] in philosophy of science and an [[Habilitation|accreditation to supervise research (HDR)]].
==Profile== Étienne Klein is a Research director at the [[Commissariat à l'énergie atomique et aux énergies alternatives|Commissariat à l'énergie atomique et aux énergies alternatives (CEA)]].<ref name="A">[http://www-centre-saclay.cea.fr/en/Klein Centre Saclay CEA]</ref> He is currently head of the Laboratoire des Recherches sur les Sciences de la Matière (LARSIM), a research laboratory belonging to the CEA and located in [[Saclay]] near Paris.<ref>[http://iramis.cea.fr/spec/Phocea/Vie_des_labos/Ast/ast_groupe.php?id_groupe=748 Laboratoire des Recherches sur les Sciences de la Matière (LARSIM)]</ref> He took part in several major projects, such as the adjustment of a [[Isotopic separation#Laser|method of isotopic separation]] involving the use of lasers, and the study of a [[particle accelerator]] with superconducting cavities. At [[CERN]] he was involved in the design of the [[Large Hadron Collider]] (LHC).<ref name="Futura">[http://www.futura-sciences.com/fr/comprendre/carte-blanche/scientifique/t/matiere/d/klein_101/ « Carte blanche à Étienne Klein », Futura-Sciences]</ref>
He taught [[quantum physics]] and [[particle physics]] at Centrale Paris for several years and currently teaches philosophy of science.<ref>[http://www.ecp.fr/home/actualite?actuID=35242 « Cours d'Étienne Klein en vidéo »]</ref> He is a specialist in the question of time in physics and has written a number of essays on the subject. He is also a member of the [[:fr:Conseil d'analyse de la société|Conseil d'analyse de la société]], of the conseil scientifique de la [[Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie|Cité des Sciences]], of the Conseil de l'[[:fr:Office parlementaire d'évaluation des choix scientifiques et technologiques|Office parlementaire d'évaluation des choix scientifiques et technologiques]] (OPECST), of the [[French Academy of Technologies]] and of the Conseil d'Orientation de l'[[:fr:Institut Diderot|Institut Diderot]].<ref name="A" /> Every Thursday morning he presents a radio chronicle, ''Le Monde selon Étienne Klein'', as well as ''La Conversation scientifique'' every Saturday afternoon, on the French public station [[France Culture]].<ref>[http://www.franceculture.fr/podcast/4488591 « Le Monde selon Étienne Klein, 2012-2013 »]</ref><ref>http://www.franceculture.fr/emissions/la-conversation-scientifique</ref>
Étienne Klein practises mountain-climbing<ref>[http://www.universcience.tv/video-etienne-klein-libido-sciendi-569.html « Étienne Klein, libido sciendi, Portrait d'Étienne Klein diffusé sur universcience.tv du 22/01 au 25/02/2010.. »]</ref> and other endurance sports.<ref>[http://www.ultratrailmb.com/page/107/Resultats.html Résultats de l’Ultra-Trail du Mont-Blanc (cherchez Klein et non pas Étienne Klein)]</ref>
== Plagiarism affair == In December 2016, Science magazine, a publication of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]], reported that Popular French physicist Étienne Klein was responsible of a plagiarism, his work was said to be plagiarizing the novelist [[Stefan Zweig]] and other authors.<ref>http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/12/popular-french-physicist-accused-plagiarizing-colleagues-and-famous-writers</ref>
